awd_titl_txt: GP-IN:  SOARING: Sharing Opportunities, Approaches, and Resources in New Geo-teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
The Rural Education Center (REC) at Kansas State University and the Center for Remote Sensing of Ice Sheets (CReSIS) at the University of Kansas will develop project SOARING: Sharing Opportunities, Approaches, and Resources in New Geo-teaching. The primary goal of Project SOARING is to provide training for secondary (middle and high school) teachers and students on the latest geotechnology for the purpose of increasing students’ desire to pursue geoscience degrees and careers. Specifically, the PIs target geotechnology applications of airborne remote sensing for geological applications. The PIs have partnered with nine school districts in which they have ongoing partnerships and that represent a diverse group of rural schools across central and western Kansas. Most of these schools have significant underrepresented populations, particularly Hispanic/Latinx populations. The KSU REC will be the lead organization, facilitating most of the grant, recruiting the teachers and students to participate in the project activities, providing support to teachers when they are in their classrooms and connecting teachers with the KSU Summer STEM Institute (SSI). The CReSIS at KU will provide content in the geosciences, resources, and instruction regarding the geoscience technology. 

Underrepresented groups in rural communities face multiple barriers to geoscience careers in comparison to their classmates in urban and suburban schools. With these purposes in mind, the objectives of Project SOARING are to: 1) train rural teachers to engage rural secondary students in geosciences activities and geotechnology; 2) to expose diverse rural secondary students to meaningful geoscience learning experiences; 3) build students’ skills and competency for geoscience degrees and careers; 4) increase the students’ desire to pursue degrees and geoscience-related careers. Rural teachers and their diverse rural students were chosen for this grant because: 1) many rural schools face teacher vacancies in all STEM related fields; 2) rural students typically score lower on STEM assessments; 3) few Earth Science classes are taught in secondary schools, especially in rural schools. The proposal outlines a series of approaches to engage twenty-seven secondary school teachers (9 per year) and potentially over four thousand students with geotechnology and resources. Additionally, the project will seek to recruit participation by female students, Hispanic/Latinx and minority students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project SOARING, launched in July 2021, hosted an eight-day hybrid professional learning session that culminated in a face-to-face meeting at the University of Kansas (KU) on July 26th. This session aimed to train four rural teachers and engage eight rural secondary students in geotechnology, specifically using remote sensing drones. During the hybrid online segment, participants were mailed the necessary drone parts and guided through assembly and sensor testing. The final face-to-face session at KU provided hands-on training in drone operation for geoscience applications and data collection using the sensors. This initiative successfully met its objectives: training rural teachers to involve their students in geosciences and exposing rural students to meaningful geoscience learning experiences. All participants successfully built and operated their drones, equipping them with practical skills and confidence in using geotechnological tools.

In May 2022, the project expanded to include a hybrid curriculum for 17 rural teachers and their students. Over the month, teachers and students built drones from scratch, equipped with lidar and cameras, supported by video tutorials and live sessions. The in-person component at KU on June 2nd and 3rd 2022, facilitated the completion and testing of these drones. Follow-up geoscience lessons were planned for the fall to further integrate drone technology into classroom learning. This iteration of the project addressed all four of its objectives to varying degrees, with a focus on engaging students in geosciences and utilizing drones for educational purposes.

The project demonstrated significant results, with 13 out of 14 teachers responding positively to the curriculum and workshops. A majority of participants agreed that the workshop provided valuable resources, increased their understanding and interest in UAS (Unmanned Aerial Systems) flight and data collection, and offered networking opportunities. Participants also noted the workshop's effectiveness in communicating the importance of UAS data collection and its practical applications, although some areas, such as the depth of topic coverage and meeting specific training goals, received slightly lower agreement rates.

One notable outcome was the increased enthusiasm among rural students about attending college, driven by their experience on the KU campus. This exposure addressed a significant barrier for rural students, particularly those from diverse backgrounds, in considering higher education and STEM careers. The project also planned for continued support and lesson development for teachers, leveraging the drones and sensors in their classrooms.

In June 2023, the project further refined its approach by using pre-constructed drones, which enabled more advanced activities and explicit connections to geoscience careers. This iteration involved 12 teachers and 24 students who participated in intensive professional development sessions led by Dr. Behzad Ghanbarian from Kansas State University. The training focused on programming and testing the drones, as well as making connections to geoscience careers. This approach proved to be the most effective in meeting the project's objectives.

Survey responses from this session indicated a high level of satisfaction among participants. All respondents agreed that the workshop provided new resources, increased understanding and interest in UAS, and was worth their time and effort. Additionally, the workshop effectively communicated the importance of UAS data collection and the diverse career opportunities in this field. Participants also appreciated the opportunity to network with other professionals interested in UAS.

Overall, Project SOARING achieved its primary goals of training rural teachers and engaging students in geosciences using drone technology. The project's broader impacts included increasing student interest in higher education and STEM careers, addressing barriers faced by rural students, and providing ongoing support and resources for teachers. The project's success has laid a strong foundation for future initiatives, with plans to expand participation and further integrate drone technology into classroom learning.

Looking ahead, the project aims to improve the quality of its curriculum and workshops based on feedback and experiences from previous sessions. The focus will be on enhancing the workshop format and time frame to better address project goals and objectives. The project also received a no-cost extension (NCE) to build on its successes and provide additional support for teachers during the school year.

The NCE support will included surveying teachers to identify their needs and developing targeted resources to enhance their use of drones and sensors in geoscience education. From this survey we decided to allow teachers to request resources in exchange for developing lessons using the UAS and equipment. For example, one teacher requested a higher quality camera and lidar to do more in depth applications with agriculure. Teachers are currently writing up their lessons to submit to the REC for sharing with teachers across the state.
